awd_titl_txt: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution/ OI/ CY 2022 - CY 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
A request is made to fund Oceanographic Instrumentation (OI) on R/V Atlantis, a 274’ general purpose research vessel, and R/V Armstrong, a 238’ multidisciplinary vessel. Both are operated by Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) as part of the U.S. Academic Research Fleet (ARF) which is scheduled by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). Both are owned by the U.S. Navy, have state-of-the-art instrumentation, and support all disciplines of oceanographic research.  The vessels work in all the world’s oceans supporting science funded primarily by U.S government agencies. R/V Atlantis is specifically outfitted for launching and servicing Alvin, the human occupied submersible as well as other vehicles of the National Deep Submergence Facility (NDSF). 

With this proposal, WHOI provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following OI:

(4) Teledyne-RDI Lowered ADCPs 	$154,860
(1) OSIL Autosal Salinometer & Accessories	$46,120
(1) AML Oceanographic Moving Vessel Profiler	$408,897
(1) McLane Large Volume Zooplankton Pump	$40,455
(1) Hydroptic Underwater Vision Profiler	$63,070
(2) RBR Concerto CTDs 	$61,204
(1) McLane Imaging FlowCytobot 	$128,250
						$902,856
						
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2022, the National Science Foundation (NSF) funded Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) for four Teledyne-RDI LADCPs, one OSIL Autosal Salinometer with Accessories, and one McLane Large Volume Zooplankton Pump.

Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) operates two research vessels, RV NEIL ARMSTRONG and RV ATLANTIS, as part of the U.S. Academic Fleet which is scheduled by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). Both vessels are owned by the U.S. Navy, have state-of-the-art instrumentation, and support all disciplines of oceanographic research. The vessels work in all the world’s oceans supporting science funded primarily by NSF and other U.S government agencies. Cruise support is provided by permanently installed shipboard equipment, a variety of land-based instrumentation, and an extensive pool of items that must be maintained ashore to ensure availability to users of all vessels.

The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use WHOI-operated research vessels and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers. Additionally, scientists assigned to other vessels in the Academic Research Fleet can request this supported equipment as a pooled resource. 

The shared-use pool of lowered ADCPs (LADCPs) has been operating at WHOI since 1995. LADCP operations have become a standard part of many hydrographic cruises and the pool has developed to the point where it supports simultaneous LADCP operations across multiple ships. The funded request was for an additional four 300kHz Workhorse Sentinel ADCPs from Teledyne-RDI to begin the gradual replacement of the existing 10-15 year old units, in order to support up to 4 cruises per year which need multiple units, each. In addition to the Workhorses, firmware and cables were also required.

Since the purchase of the requested LADCPs, they have been deployed and scheduled on eleven NSF-sponsored expeditions on ships across the Academic Research Fleet, including: 7 NSF-sponsored expeditions on WHOI-operated RV NEIL ARMSTRONG, 2 NSF-sponsored projects on URI-operated RV ENDEAVOR, 1 NSF-sponsored project on UCSD-operated RV ROGER REVELLE, and 1 NSF-sponsored project on Greenland-operated RV TARAJOQ.

Autosals are the most user friendly salinometer to use at-sea for quick salinity data associated with CTD field work. The new OSIL unit was received late Fall 2022, and immediately was employed in a shore-based laboratory and proven to be the hoped-for addition to the salinometer pool for shared use. While in the lab, the salinometer ran several hundred samples returned from the field by various projects, before being deployed at sea for the first time. The new salinometer was deployed on several 2023 OOI expeditions to OOI-Irminger, in the Irminger sea off southern Greenland, and OOI-Pioneer South, the new location of the Pioneer array proximal to Nags Head, North Carolina. Anticipated future at-sea use includes PIs from University of Miami and University of Texas at Austin. The new unit could not have been acquired at a better time, given that shortly after its arrival, one of the 30-year old units WHOI formerly relied on had to be returned to its manufacturer for significant overhaul and repair.

Large volume benthic pumps for in situ zooplankton collection are in increasingly high demand in the scientific community. In response to the number of requests, WHOI was funded for an additional McLane WTS-6-1-142LVUP pump for the shared use pool. These pumps are the best way to collect zooplankton at a discrete location, such as near a specific seafloor feature or benthic community. McLane pumps have a high-volume pump head (30 L/min) that allows for quantitative samples of up to 40,000 L. These large samples are essential for collection of plankton that are rare in deep water, such as larvae of benthic species. Additionally, the filter assembly is specially designed with a large head space and thick insulation to ensure that the specimens come to the surface at cold seafloor temperatures, in good condition, and in many cases still alive. The pumps are reliable, durable, and easy to use. They have become the go-to option for deep sampling of larvae, replacing nets and other towed systems.

WHOI received the McLane WTS-LVUP zooplankton pump with new 3rd gen electronics in October 2022. It was first deployed on AT50-04: Seep Larval Dispersal (Chief Sci, Craig Young at University of Oregon) in October and November 2022 to collect larvae of benthic invertebrates from near-seafloor environments in conjunction with HOV ALVIN. Since that time, the zooplankton pumps in the shared-use inventory have been requested for 6 different NSF-funded expeditions.

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2024
Modified by: Sarah Fuller
